body: The Sad Queen

reblog.comment: The Sad Queen

trail.content_raw: The Sad Queen

summary:
Okay, listen. I am and always have been the biggest Daenerys fan. 
But when she called Gandry’s name during the banquet in 8x04,...
body:
Okay, listen. I am and always have been the biggest Daenerys fan.

But when she called Gandry’s name during the banquet in 8x04, in the few beats before she declared him Gendry Baratheon, my heart stopped. You could tell everyone on screens did too and I’m sure most of the fandom’s did as well.

And I think that was the point.

I love Dany, but I never know what she is going to do or say. If Jon had called out Gendry, or anyone else’s name, I wouldn’t be as nervous about what he would do.

What happens 10, 20, 50 years from now? Is everyone still trying to talk her out of everything? Will she temper, or will her temper get worse?

blog.name: hamliet
blog.title: to write or not to write
blog.description: I write meta & fic for stories I like. Often anime/manga focused. Redemption arcs, existentialism, and well-executed romances are a few of my favorite things.

summary: (1) Janos Slynt was a baby killer who deserved to die long before Jon Snow executed him. Randyll Tarly was a terrible person. I...
question: (1) Janos Slynt was a baby killer who deserved to die long before Jon Snow executed him. Randyll Tarly was a terrible person. I never cared for him. Dickon, however, seemed like a decent man. That’s why I took issue with Daenerys burning Dickon alive, especially since he was the brother of the same man who cured one of her closest friends.
answer:
(2) I’m surprised Jon didn’t make a bigger issue out of that with Daenerys. If Sansa and Arya found out about that as well, then I would understand their refusal to trust her. However, the writers just make the Stark sisters seem xenophobic and ungrateful toward the woman who helped ensure their survival against the White Walkers.

(3) Then, there’s the hype around Daenerys becoming a “Mad Queen” similar to how her father became the “Mad King.” Do people realize how prejudiced that is toward people with family histories of mental health issues?

Well, I do think that it’s worth noting that Dany did not know Sam had cured Jorah at that point–she and Jorah did not reunite until later that same episode. She’d have no way of knowing Dickon was a decent man (and he did seem to be) and he was supporting someone who was not (his father). 

That said, I actually completely agree that her burning them was stupid strategically and bad morally, but I don’t think Dany realized just how bad it was and people forget that just because we the audience knew, she absolutely did not. I do appreciate that the show shows consequences for her for that though and actually think Sam’s mistrust was justified.

But exactly like you say, Sansa and Arya’s mistrust is ridiculous. If they’re playing Tyrion and Varys like they played Littlefinger I can forgive a bit though it’s still, just like the Sansa vs. Arya plot last season, just plain bad writing, but if not… like #yikes. You can’t have your heroes say the exact same thing your villain said (”she’s not one of us”) and frame them as right for it. You just can’t. And they forgave Theon and Sansa gave Littlefinger chance after chance after chance and doesn’t give that to Dany… why exactly? We’re never given a concrete reason and it is just so out of character. It also doesn’t play well when such a statement is coupled with the blatant and deliberate displays of racism in the North. You really wanna endorse the racism which at least several leaked possible endings would? You sure, HBO? D&D can kiss Star Wars goodbye if so. 

YEAH. That’s a big thing with the ableism. Racist, misogynistic, and ableist, what a winning combo. Like, really HBO? Really? Even if this is just baiting, and I have to believe it is because I can’t fathom the show putting her down as a mad dog (yes I’m up to date on leaks and the confusion continues), it’s irresponsible of the showrunners to set it up like this and to (apparently) actually hire people to drop half-true half-false leaks (according to a reliable source–Javi) so no one knows what the truth is. And they’ve yet to show us any kind of evidence she’s unstable and not just, idk, experiencing emotions like a normal person going through loss. At this point it’s too late for them to pull it off in a believable way; even if the story does go there, they will be rightfully excoriated for it, for sending the message that if you experience just enough tragedy even if your motif through 7 seasons has always been bringing life from death, you might just go insane. 

We know Dany has a good heart. IF she goes mad, it’s not her revealing what she’s always been deep down. It’s her breaking after so much tragedy. That’s not a villain; that’s a tragedy. And it isn’t Shakespearean either because Shakespearean tragedies rest highly on the characters’ choices and Dany’s… would just be literally manipulating rules of reality to take everything from her to drive her insane (sorry, Euron’s fleet taking Rhaegal and capturing Missandei was unrealistic AF). The next person I see disrespecting the Bard by comparing this mess to him… For tragedy to work, it has to not feel forced. This feels so forced I can only hope it’s baiting instead of lulz look at the mad dog queen. And it would also make Missandei’s death be like… even more pointless because why establish Cersei as Bad Bad Bad (like we didn’t know) if Cersei will just be another victim of Mad Dany? 

Sigh. I’m anxious rn. I wish I had something else in life to distract me, but I kinda don’t right now. My highs come from fiction, which is rather sad. Life, have mercy.

blog.name: instantbouquetface-me
blog.title: Look! It's a bird! It's a plane!...It's a speck on my glasses...

summary: I have a problem believing both leak the bellgate seem just too much, extreme....specifically in 2019 to be completely...
question: I have a problem believing both leak the bellgate seem just too much, extreme....specifically in 2019 to be completely real...but at this point I have real trouble to see tyrion just coldly frame (for his sister who still hate him ) Dany . When he was defended her, pratically begged varys to save her life. But, I do believe tyrion will do smt...just hope it will make sense I think tyrion writing is so inconsistent
answer:
Hi Nonny,

The problem is that the leaks have multiple characters behaving completely out of character. Behaving in ways that the preparatory groundwork (needed for the audience to suspect that something like this was coming) done in seven and a half seasons simply would not lead us to expect.

We are to believe that Dany just completely loses her mind… after hearing bells. As if she has not known loss before. As if there is some significant trauma in her life that would be triggered by hearing bells. And the Unsullied are shown to lose their discipline. The guys who didn’t lose discipline in the face of the Army of the Dead (where many of their colleagues died) are to lose their discipline. I can understand this for Grey Worm, but what of the rest of the unit?

Then we have Jon killing the love of his life. If this is to be made palatable at all then Dany has to be so dangerous and insane at this juncture that she’d make Viserys look like Bran. You know like trying to Dracarys Jon etc. Otherwise why would he just blindly believe that Tyrion’s account of her going full-on Aerys insane was the truth? Wouldn’t he try to verify this himself?

And the problem with Tyrion is that as of 8x04 I still don’t really detect treason from him. He does seem to have divided loyalties between wanting to keep his sister safe and serving Dany. If consistency is to be maintained in any sense then their ought to be some continuity to his motivations. What will this be?

The problem, however, is that right now the confidence level in D&D’s desire to maintain logic and consistency is at an all time low. They simply don’t seem interested in it so far this season. It really seems like they are willing to throw logic to the wind to get cool shots and shocking scenes. What else is one to make of an entire fleet being missed by Dany and her fleet on the open sea under a clear sky, and Euron just managing to kill Rhaegal like this?

Here is what happened to Prince Morion (these Scorpions are not a new technology you know)


Dorne had not boasted any strength at sea since Nymeria burned her ten thousand ships, but Prince Morion did have gold, and he found willing allies in the pirates of the Stepstones, the sellsails of Myr, and the corsairs of the Pepper Coast. Though it took him the best part of a year, eventually the ships came straggling in, and the prince and his spearmen were loaded aboard. Morion had been weaned on the tales of past Dornish glory, and like many young Dornish lords he had seen the sun mottled bones of the dragon Meraxes at the Hellholt. Every ship in his fleet was therefore manned with crossbowmen and equipped with massive scorpions of the sort that had felled Meraxes. If the Targaryens dared to send dragons against him, he would fill the air with bolts and kill them all…

Jaehaerys Targaryen and his sons Aemon and Baelon had been waiting as well, and as Morion’s fleet beat its way across the Sea of Dorne, the dragons Vermithor, Caraxes, and Vhagar fell on them from out of the clouds. Shouts rang out, and the Dornish filled the air with scorpion bolts, but firing at a dragon is one thing, and killing it quite another. A few bolts glanced off the scales of the dragons, and one punched through Vhagar’s wing, but none of them found any vulnerable spots as the dragons swooped and banked and loosed great blasts of fire. One by one the ships went up in gouts of flame. They were still burning when the sun went down, “like a hundred candles floating on the sea.” Burned bodies would wash up on the shores of Cape Wrath for half a year, but not a single living Dornishman set foot upon the stormlands.

The Fourth Dornish War was fought and won in a single day. The pirates of the Stepstones, the sellsails of Myr, and the corsairs of the Pepper Coast became less troublesome for a time, and Mara Martell became the Princess of Dorne. Back in King’s Landing, King Jaehaerys and his sons received a riotous welcome. Even Aegon the Conqueror had never won a war without losing a man. (F&B)

When the show goes in this direction it becomes very hard to trust anything.

For example before 8x04 I would have said that a leak saying that Jon just leaves Ghost without so much as a pet and sends him North would not happen. That the showrunners know that the audience itself has adopted Ghost as a pet and there needs to be more emotion in this scene. But it did happen. So that is what makes it hard to rule things out on logic.

The problem, however, is that right now the confidence level in D&D’s desire to maintain logic and consistency is at an all time low. They simply don’t seem interested in it so far this season. It really seems like they are willing to throw logic to the wind to get cool shots and shocking scenes. What else is one to make of an entire fleet being missed by Dany and her fleet on the open sea under a clear sky, and Euron just managing to kill Rhaegal like this?

Here is what happened to Prince Morion (these Scorpions are not a new technology you know)


Dorne had not boasted any strength at sea since Nymeria burned her ten thousand ships, but Prince Morion did have gold, and he found willing allies in the pirates of the Stepstones, the sellsails of Myr, and the corsairs of the Pepper Coast. Though it took him the best part of a year, eventually the ships came straggling in, and the prince and his spearmen were loaded aboard. Morion had been weaned on the tales of past Dornish glory, and like many young Dornish lords he had seen the sun mottled bones of the dragon Meraxes at the Hellholt. Every ship in his fleet was therefore manned with crossbowmen and equipped with massive scorpions of the sort that had felled Meraxes. If the Targaryens dared to send dragons against him, he would fill the air with bolts and kill them all…

Jaehaerys Targaryen and his sons Aemon and Baelon had been waiting as well, and as Morion’s fleet beat its way across the Sea of Dorne, the dragons Vermithor, Caraxes, and Vhagar fell on them from out of the clouds. Shouts rang out, and the Dornish filled the air with scorpion bolts, but firing at a dragon is one thing, and killing it quite another. A few bolts glanced off the scales of the dragons, and one punched through Vhagar’s wing, but none of them found any vulnerable spots as the dragons swooped and banked and loosed great blasts of fire. One by one the ships went up in gouts of flame. They were still burning when the sun went down, “like a hundred candles floating on the sea.” Burned bodies would wash up on the shores of Cape Wrath for half a year, but not a single living Dornishman set foot upon the stormlands.

The Fourth Dornish War was fought and won in a single day. The pirates of the Stepstones, the sellsails of Myr, and the corsairs of the Pepper Coast became less troublesome for a time, and Mara Martell became the Princess of Dorne. Back in King’s Landing, King Jaehaerys and his sons received a riotous welcome. Even Aegon the Conqueror had never won a war without losing a man. (F&B)

When the show goes in this direction it becomes very hard to trust anything.

For example before 8x04 I would have said that a leak saying that Jon just leaves Ghost without so much as a pet and sends him North would not happen. That the showrunners know that the audience itself has adopted Ghost as a pet and there needs to be more emotion in this scene. But it did happen. So that is what makes it hard to rule things out on logic.
trail.content:
Hi Nonny,

The problem is that the leaks have multiple characters behaving completely out of character. Behaving in ways that the preparatory groundwork (needed for the audience to suspect that something like this was coming) done in seven and a half seasons simply would not lead us to expect.

We are to believe that Dany just completely loses her mind… after hearing bells. As if she has not known loss before. As if there is some significant trauma in her life that would be triggered by hearing bells. And the Unsullied are shown to lose their discipline. The guys who didn’t lose discipline in the face of the Army of the Dead (where many of their colleagues died) are to lose their discipline. I can understand this for Grey Worm, but what of the rest of the unit?

Then we have Jon killing the love of his life. If this is to be made palatable at all then Dany has to be so dangerous and insane at this juncture that she’d make Viserys look like Bran. You know like trying to Dracarys Jon etc. Otherwise why would he just blindly believe that Tyrion’s account of her going full-on Aerys insane was the truth? Wouldn’t he try to verify this himself?

And the problem with Tyrion is that as of 8x04 I still don’t really detect treason from him. He does seem to have divided loyalties between wanting to keep his sister safe and serving Dany. If consistency is to be maintained in any sense then their ought to be some continuity to his motivations. What will this be?

The problem, however, is that right now the confidence level in D&D’s desire to maintain logic and consistency is at an all time low. They simply don’t seem interested in it so far this season. It really seems like they are willing to throw logic to the wind to get cool shots and shocking scenes. What else is one to make of an entire fleet being missed by Dany and her fleet on the open sea under a clear sky, and Euron just managing to kill Rhaegal like this?

Here is what happened to Prince Morion (these Scorpions are not a new technology you know)


Dorne had not boasted any strength at sea since Nymeria burned her ten thousand ships, but Prince Morion did have gold, and he found willing allies in the pirates of the Stepstones, the sellsails of Myr, and the corsairs of the Pepper Coast. Though it took him the best part of a year, eventually the ships came straggling in, and the prince and his spearmen were loaded aboard. Morion had been weaned on the tales of past Dornish glory, and like many young Dornish lords he had seen the sun mottled bones of the dragon Meraxes at the Hellholt. Every ship in his fleet was therefore manned with crossbowmen and equipped with massive scorpions of the sort that had felled Meraxes. If the Targaryens dared to send dragons against him, he would fill the air with bolts and kill them all…

Jaehaerys Targaryen and his sons Aemon and Baelon had been waiting as well, and as Morion’s fleet beat its way across the Sea of Dorne, the dragons Vermithor, Caraxes, and Vhagar fell on them from out of the clouds. Shouts rang out, and the Dornish filled the air with scorpion bolts, but firing at a dragon is one thing, and killing it quite another. A few bolts glanced off the scales of the dragons, and one punched through Vhagar’s wing, but none of them found any vulnerable spots as the dragons swooped and banked and loosed great blasts of fire. One by one the ships went up in gouts of flame. They were still burning when the sun went down, “like a hundred candles floating on the sea.” Burned bodies would wash up on the shores of Cape Wrath for half a year, but not a single living Dornishman set foot upon the stormlands.

The Fourth Dornish War was fought and won in a single day. The pirates of the Stepstones, the sellsails of Myr, and the corsairs of the Pepper Coast became less troublesome for a time, and Mara Martell became the Princess of Dorne. Back in King’s Landing, King Jaehaerys and his sons received a riotous welcome. Even Aegon the Conqueror had never won a war without losing a man. (F&B)

When the show goes in this direction it becomes very hard to trust anything.

For example before 8x04 I would have said that a leak saying that Jon just leaves Ghost without so much as a pet and sends him North would not happen. That the showrunners know that the audience itself has adopted Ghost as a pet and there needs to be more emotion in this scene. But it did happen. So that is what makes it hard to rule things out on logic.

summary: Look, I used to love Jon Snow, he used to be one of my favorite character, keyword used to be. Look Jon, if you really loved...
body: Look, I used to love Jon Snow, he used to be one of my favorite character, keyword used to be. Look Jon, if you really loved Daenerys so much you woulda kept this secret. You already owe this woman your life like three times over and the least you could do is save hers for once. Jon doesn’t even want the throne so what’s the point. Your home boi Ned took the secret to his grave so I’m thinking you could too.

blog.name: gameofthronesrewritten
blog.title: GOT Rewritten
blog.description:
“What do we say to the god of death?”

“Not today.”

body:
Intro Post

Alright, so I have to admit this is a lot to undertake. Let me explain, first.

I’m not intending on rewriting every book in its entirety. Instead, I will be posting about what will have changed, with the occasional drabble and, perhaps, even a chaptered work. I also will be mixing show and movie canon- for example, I’m keeping ages the same as they are in the show, but I’m not following the same route the show goes after the divergence.

This will leave out some characters, and add in some others. It will eliminate most of the incest, rape, and pedophilia, and the rare times it is mentioned will come with trigger warnings. I may also be switching around canonical family trees.

The rewrite will include lgbt characters, poc who do NOT die (or, at least, not all of them die), and representation of mental illnesses. It will not eliminate all of the sexism, but this will be cultural views, not necessarily the views of the characters.

Most of all, I want to stress that this is for fun. I’m not trying to say I could do it better, I just want to explore the world in a way that satisfies me. That being said, I will accept questions and critique, so long as it is worded politely.

summary: tfw you realize emilia clarke filmed GOT while fearing for her life and thinking she was dying from brain aneurysms but playing...

summary: There are four main female characters in the show, Dany, Cersei, Sansa and Arya and all of them are portrayed as either...
body: There are four main female characters in the show, Dany, Cersei, Sansa and Arya and all of them are portrayed as either villainous or problematic in one way or another.  And yet the main male characters are portrayed as the voices of reason. It makes me sick.

reblog.comment: There are four main female characters in the show, Dany, Cersei, Sansa and Arya and all of them are portrayed as either villainous or problematic in one way or another.  And yet the main male characters are portrayed as the voices of reason. It makes me sick.

summary: Soooooooo Dany is furious and sad because she just lost her child, her best friend and her protector, so yeah, she decided to...
title: Soooooooo Dany is furious and sad because she just lost her child, her best friend and her protector, so yeah, she decided to burn them all, because her emotions are all over the place. I would do the same thing in her situation. Who wouldn’t? Yet everyone is now calling her a mad queen ,like wtf? Do we watch the same show? So mad at the writers and everyone else because a strong female character can’t show anger without being called crazy, and go mad, or become a villain. Fuck you all. I know they intend to make her a bad person and I don’t believe it for a second. They gonna kill her character and i’m gonna kill someone for that. Fuck.
